loan.name: Lolita

texts.en: Lolita is 58 years old, married and has four children. She is in the agricultural business, farming vegetables in the Philippines. Lolita requested a 12,000 Philippine peso loan through NWTF to purchase fertilizers and pesticides for her vegetable farming. Lolita has been farming vegetables for seven years now and has borrowed 15 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it. In the future, Lolita would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loan.use: to purchase fertilizers and pesticides for her vegetable farming.

payment.comment: Over-reported by partner. Reduced to local price.

loan.name: Rosarah

texts.en:
Rosarah is 38 years old and married with three children.
She earns a living by farming vegetables in the Philippines. Rosarah is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to buy pesticides and fertilizers for her vegetable farming.
Rosarah has been farming vegetables for nine years and also earns additional income from being an Avon dealer, selling Ready-To-Wear and livestock raising.
She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loan.use: To buy pesticides and fertilizers for her vegetable farming.

payment.comment: Over-reported by partner. Reduced to local price.

loan.name: Ellen

texts.en: Ellen is 33 years old, married and has two children who are in school. Ellen is in the agricultural business, raising pigs in the Philippines. She requested a 15,000 Philippine peso loan through NWTF to purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs. Ellen has been raising pigs for four years now and has borrowed seven times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business. Ellen would like to save enough money so that she can afford to send her children to college and expand her business in the future.

loan.use: to purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs.

payment.comment: Over-reported by partner. Reduced to local price.

loan.name: Buyanbat

texts.en:
Buyanbat is 64 years old and lives with her husband and only son in a ger (a Mongolian traditional nomadic housing tent) in Hovd province, Mongolia. Her son is a driver who has operated a transportation service for 10 years in his town.
Buyanbat manages a food cafe with the help of her husband. They started their business in 1999 and are planning to continue their business in the future. They offer a variety of Mongolian traditional dishes including buuz, huushuur, lapsha and tsuivan, etc. Their meals are well-known amongst their customers for quality and freshness.
With years of business operation, they gained much experience and have been able to build a house where they can prepare meals for their customers. Buyanbat is an honest and polite woman who says, "I am doing my best in order to provide better living conditions for my family."
She is requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan to renew her son's truck in order to support her son's transportation business.

loan.use: to renew her son's truck

loan.name: Elsie

texts.en:
Elsie is a hard-working entrepreneur who has a fishing business in the Philippines. She is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to purchase fishing gear and equipment for her fishing business. Elsie has been in this business for 24 years. She earns additional income from fish vending.
Elsie has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving enough money so she can afford to send her children to college in the future.

loan.use: To purchase fishing gear and equipment.

loan.name: Vevencia

texts.en: Vevencia is 38 years old and married with two children. She works hard to provide for her family. Vevencia runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and requested a 22,000 Philippine peso loan through NWTF to buy items like sardines, groceries, etc., to sell in her sari-sari store. Vevencia has borrowed and repaid 19 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for three years and also earns income from furniture and raising livestock. Vevencia aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loan.use: to buy more items to sell in her general store.

payment.comment: Over-reported by partner. Reduced to local price.

loan.name: Marivie

texts.en:
Meeting lifes challenges head on is a habit that could be developed only by the brave. Marivie P., 28, does just that. Marivie is only a high school graduate but right now she manages her own micro-business as she learns entrepreneurship as a community partner in CCT*. She is married to Joenard, who is a driver, and mothers her three children, who are now in elementary school.
For six years now, Marivie has been in the coconut business. She buys young coconut fruit directly from farmers and she retails them. She has a fruit stand along the highway by-pass leading to Tagaytay City, a local tourist destination in the province. Marivie also sells coconut by-products like pure coco vinegar and coco wine. She earns an estimated net monthly income of around 12,000 PHP from this business.
To help her continue the operation of her business, she is requesting a 20,000 PHP loan. She intends to use this loan to purchase more fresh young coconuts for selling.
Marivie acknowledges that no challenges are too hard to deal with. She knows that the Lord will enable her to overcome and uphold the future of both her children and her business. She dreams of making her sari-sari store grow. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she received.
*All CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loan.use: to pay for fresh buko fruits (young coconut fruit) to sell

loan.name: Susana

texts.en:
As a married parent of six children, Susana works hard to support her family.
She has a fishing business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from food vending. Susana is borrowing 15,000 PHP (Philippine Peso) through NWTF to buy equipment for her fishing business.
Susana has been sustaining her business by successfully repaying five previous loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so that she can send her children to college.

loan.use: To purchase fishing equipment

loan.name: Flordeliza

texts.en:
Flordeliza is 69 years old, married and she has three children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur.
Flordeliza has a tailoring business in the Philippines. She requested a 20,000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) loan through NWTF to buy threads, needles, scissors, tape measure, garments, and buttons for her tailoring business.
Flordeliza has been in this business for 50 years. In the future, Flordeliza would like to save money to expand her business.

loan.use: To buy additional materials for her tailoring business

payment.comment: Over-reported by partner. Reduced to local price.

loan.name: Peregrina

texts.en:
Peregrina is 49 years old, married and has one child. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur.
Peregrina has a food production business in the Philippines. She has requested a loan of 14,000 PHP through Kiva partner, NWTF, to buy ingredients for her food production business. Peregrina has been in this business for three years. In the future, she would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loan.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business.

loan.name: Mercedita

texts.en:
Mercedita is 61 years old, married and has six children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and has requested a 20,000 PHP loan through Kiva partner, NWTF, to buy items to sell in her sari-sari store such as shampoo, groceries, etc.
Mercedita has borrowed and paid back 12 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for 31 years and also earns an income from rice retailing and rice farming. She aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loan.use: to buy items for her general store.

loan.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is 50 years old, married and has three children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and has requested a 16,000 PHP loan through Kiva partner, NWTF, to buy more stock to sell.
Lydia has borrowed and paid back three loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running her sari-sari store for two years and also earns an income from abaca weaving. She aspires to repair and renovate her house to secure her family's future.

loan.use: to purchase more stock to sell.

loan.name: Lilibeth

texts.en:
As a married parent of two children, Lilibeth works hard to support her family. She has a tricycle transport rental business in the Philippines. Lilibeth has requested a loan of 21,000 PHP through Kiva partner, NWTF, to buy new tools and equipment for her tricycle transport rental business.
Lilibeth has been in this business for five years. In the future, she would like to save enough money to be able to afford to send her children to college.

loan.use: to purchase new tools and equipment.

loan.name: Ganbold

texts.en:
Ganbold is 38 years old and lives with his wife and three children in a ger (a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent) in Hovd province, Mongolia. His older two children, ages 9 and 13, go to a local secondary school while the youngest one, who hasnt reached school age, stays home.
He manages a metal welding business, with the help of his wife, in their town. He is responsible for making metal household goods including cups, spoons, forks, etc., and his wife is responsible for selling them. He specialized in making a traditional Mongolian oven used at almost all homes in the Mongolian countryside area. His business is quite profitable which allowed him to employ one more worker at his workshop.
He is a polite man who attributes his business success to his good communication skills. He says, "I am trying hard to feed my family and I want to have my own car in the near future." He is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more iron for his business.

loan.use: to purchase more iron

loan.name: Jargalsaikhan

texts.en:
Mr. Jargalsaikhan is 48 years old and lives with his wife and son in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His eldest daughter is married and lives separately with her family.
Jargalsaikhan is a driver and runs a transportation business. He owns a minivan and transports people on one of the remote bus routes of Ulaanbaatar which lacks buses. He has special permission from city council to carry people on specific routes. Jargalsaikhan is a hardworking, sociable person.
In 2010, he bought a plot of land and is planning to build a house on it. He lives in a ger (a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent) at the moment. He has a building project on hand and is planning to start the project now.
The loan Mr. Jargalsaikhan is requesting will be used to buy necessary building materials such as cement, bricks, wooden planks, sand and so on to build a family house.

loan.use: to buy building materials such as cement, bricks, wooden planks, sand, etc. to build a family house.

loan.name: Jyldyzkan's Group

texts.en:
Jyldyzkan S. is the leader of this group. She is the resident of Karabalta, a small town near to Bishkek (capital of Kyrgyzstan). She is 44 and married. Together with her husband she is bringing up four sons. Two older sons study at university and the others are at school. In order to earn money to meet family needs, eight years ago Jyldyzkan started to breed poultry and then sell it on the market with an initial investment of 300 soms. In this way the family earns 20000 soms per month.
Jyldyzkan applied for the loan because she needs additional money to purchase more chickens for breeding. In the future she wants to give her sons good educations, purchase a vehicle and build a big house for the family.
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loan.use: To purchase chickens

loan.name: Precila

texts.en:
Precila P., who is 35, aims for completeness in life. Precila is a college undergraduate and is happily married to Rolly, a farmer. They have been blessed with a good and sustainable flower farm for years now. Together, they live in Pooc 2, Silang, Cavite, Philippines.
Precila has been raising and selling all kinds of flowers and ornamental plants for years now. She raises ornamental plants and flowers which are normally present at Filipino home gardens. She serves hobbyists, offices, schools and her local community. Along with this business, she also manages a variety store which is adjacent to her house. Every month, Precila earns an estimated net income of around 11,000 Philippine pesos (PHP).
To help her continue operation of her businesses, she is requesting a 15,000 PHP loan. She plans to use this to pay for sacks of fertilizers for her flower and ornamental plants farm. She also intends to use part of this loan to buy additional grocery items as replenishment for her variety store.
Precila desires a big grocery store and able to buy their own house and lot someday. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the groups weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she received.
*All CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loan.use: To pay for sacks of fertilizers for her flower farm and additional grocery items for her variety store.

loan.name: Sally

texts.en:
Sally is 63 years old and a widow with six children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. She has a dried fish/shrimp paste making business in the Philippines. Sally requested a PHP 12,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy more dried fish to sell in her stall.
Sally has been 20 years in this business. In the future, Sally would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loan.use: To purchase more dried fish to sell in her stall.

payment.comment: Over-reported by partner. Reduced to local price.

loan.name: Batikul's Group

texts.en:
Batikul J. is the leader of this group. She is 47 and married. Together with her husband she has raised two sons. The first son works as a security guard and the second helps his parents in farming. Twenty years ago Batikuls parents presented her with a cow and since that moment she has been selling milk products. In this way she earns 5500 soms per month. This profit made it possible for her to improve the familys living conditions. The family also cultivates agricultural products and then sells some part of the harvest on the market.
Batikul needs to purchase fuel for farming. It is for this purpose that she applied for the loan. She hopes to obtain the loan in order to realize her plans.
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loan.use: To purchase fuel

loan.name: Jesibel

texts.en:
Jecibel P., who is 37, aims for completeness in life. Jecibel completed high school and is in relationship right now with Richard Domasig, a carpenter. They have been blessed with four children who are currently studying in elementary school. Together they live in Balubad, Silang, Cavite, Philippines.
Jecibel has been retailing rice to her neighbors for quite a few years now. Basically, she buys sacks of rice at a wholesale price and retails them to her neighbors by the kilo with a minimum mark up. Along with this, she also incorporates within her store the retailing of cell phone load credits to all mobile network users among her community. Monthly, she earns an estimated net income of around Php10,000.
To help her continue operation of her businesses, she is requesting a 10,000 PHP loan. She plans to use this to pay for additional sacks of rice and purchase more cell phone load credits for retailing.
Jecibel desires a successful business, a healthy body, and a peaceful and happy life. She also prays that she will be able to send all her children all the way through college. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the groups weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she received.
*All CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loan.use: To pay for additional sacks of rice and more cell phone credits for retailing

loan.name: Bahtyhan's Group

texts.en:
Bahtyhan M., 46, is the leader of this group. Unfortunately she is a widow. She has raised three sons; two older sons went to work in Russia and the youngest son works on the railway station. Bahtyhan is engaged in cattle breeding. She started this activity when she was sixteen. She sells milk products and her monthly income is 3600 soms.
Bahtyhan applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase a sewing machine. She wants to start sewing Kyrgyz national blankets, cloth and dressmaking supplies. In the future she wants to save money and purchase a vehicle for the family.
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loan.use: To purchase a sewing machine

loan.name: Battsetseg

texts.en:
Mrs.Battsetseg is 34 years old and lives with her husband and four teenage children in rented house in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. A few years ago she married her present husband and at that time they had two children each. They had to start a new life together from scratch.
In 2004 Battsetseg started her silver jewelry retail business and since then her business has been doing very well. In 2008 she took a loan from us and started selling souvenir items, expanding her business. She is one of our VIP clients now. Her husband works as a sales manager. Recently they received a very good offer on a small plot of land and they are planning to buy it in order to build a house on it later. The loan Mrs. Battsetseg is asking for will be used to buy the plot of land to build a family house.

loan.use: To buy a small plot of land on which to build a family house in the near future.

loan.name: Lennie

texts.en:
Lennie R., who is 45, aims for completeness in life. Hermosa completed high school and is married to Geraldo, a tricycle driver. They have been blessed with three children who are currently studying in public elementary school nearby. Together, they live in Munting Ilog, Silang, Cavite, Philippines.
Lennie has been a tricycle operator for years now. Her husband used to be the driver of their tricycle unit. Every day, her husband earns an estimated net income of around 300-500 PHP. To help her husband earn more, Lennie is also selling branded apparel and footwear to her neighbors and community.
She is requesting a 19,000 PHP loan to help her continue operation of her businesses. She plans to use this to pay for the repair of their tricycle and plans to purchase a new tricycle unit. Part of this loan will be used to purchase apparel and footwear ordered in advance by her customers.
Lennie desires a successful business, a healthy body, and a peaceful and happy life. She also prays that her house will be renovated before the end of this year. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the groups weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she received.
*All CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loan.use: To pay for the repair of their tricycle unit and for the partial payment towards a new tricycle unit

loan.name: Aisalkyn's Group

texts.en:
Aisalkyn E. is the leader of this group. She is the resident of Kadamjai, a southern town next to Uzbek boarder. She is 53 and married to a private driver. Together with her husband she has raised three sons and a daughter. The first son is a military, the second went to work in Russia and the youngest helps his parents with housework.
In order to earn money Aisalkyn breeds livestock animals and then resells them at the higher price after fattening. Her parents were doing this long time ago, so Aisalkyn continues her familys traditions. She earns 1000 soms per month. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase three more goats for breeding.
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loan.use: To purchase goats

loan.name: Anonymous Group
loan.use: To purchase an electric tailoring machine in order to be able to sew more modern cloths

loan.name: Asel's Group

texts.en:
Asel S. is the treasurer of this group. She is 35 years-old and married to a shepherd. Together with her husband, she is bringing up a daughter and a son; both children are at school. Asel works as a head teacher in the local school. Her husband breeds sheep and gets money for that, from 2000 to 7000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, Asel plans to purchase goats for breeding. She can earn good money as well selling the wool. In the future, she wants to expand this kind of business and improve the familys living condition.
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line People (building human capital and taking care of its customers, as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loan.use: to purchase goats

loan.name: Kalonvi

texts.en: Kalonvi B. lives in the region of Jilikul. She is 45 years old. She is married and has five children. Her children and husband work in the collective farm. Kalonvi does agriculture. She has a big plot of land at home where she sows wheat and potatoes. She has been in this business for four years. The purpose of the loan is to buy mineral fertilizer for the sowing.

loan.use: to buy mineral fertilizer

loan.name: Shaigul's Group

texts.en:
Shaigul B. is the treasurer of this group. She is 49 years-old and married. She is a resident of Kochkor, a small village in Isykul region. Together with her husband, she has raised two daughters and a son. The daughters are married and live separately with their families. The son is 10 years-old, he studies at school. Shaigul and her husband are farmers. They cultivate agricultural products and breed livestock animals. The family has been doing it since 1991. Shaigul applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase fuel, which is needed for the sowing process. In the futurem she wants to improve her familys living condition.
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line People (building human capital and taking care of its customers, as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loan.use: to purchase fuel

loan.name: Marivic

texts.en:
This is Marivic O., 43. She is a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Flaviano O., a maintenance man. She is the mother of three children, one of whom is already working and the other two are still studying one in college and one in high school. By the grace of God, Marivic has managed to support her older children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to send her youngest to college. This is the dream for most Filipino parents like Marivic, as she herself has been a college graduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.
Marivic does a little sideline work besides her handwoven bags and scapulars business: she has a trading business. What she basically does is buy general merchandise from wholesalers, then sells items piecemeal with a small profit. Products can range from furniture to household appliances, electronic devices, clothing, and other items. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling prices and the many options that are offered. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 300 in sales every day.
To help her continue the operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 10,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
Marivic dreams to be able to give her all her children a high-quality education through all her hard work on her business. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives.
* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loan.use: to pay for additional merchandise to sell

loan.name: Amal

texts.en:
Amal is a 23-year-old lady who is married to Mohammad, 29 years old, and has three children. Her husband owns a pick-up and uses it to sell fruits and vegetables around the area. Amal wanted to help her husband in supporting their family. So she thought about the access her husband has to fresh vegetables and she decided to start a home-based business cutting (chopping) potatoes and selling them to the restaurants around the area.
Due to the high number of orders she gets, she is now applying for a loan to buy a special machine to chop and cut potatoes in a faster way, so she can increase her productivity and to be able to help her husband in his business.

loan.use: To buy a special machine for chopping and cutting potatoes in a faster way

loan.name: Ismael

texts.en: Ismael A. S. is a 29-year-old hard working man who is married to Nariman and has four children. In order to support his family, he started his own business five years ago by opening a metal works (blacksmith) shop in a very active area in his city, a place everyone can easily reach and a place that has a good reputation. Thats what helped him gain a lot of customers. To be able to serve as many customers as he can, he applied for this loan to buy more machines and tools to help him accelerate his productivity.

loan.use: To buy more machines and tools to help him accelerate his productivity

loan.name: Nenita

texts.en:
This is Nenita D. R., 37 years-old. She is a resident of Pangarap Village, Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Rinel, a businessman. She is the mother of two high school children. At this time, she is working hard to send her two children to college. This is the dream for most Filipino parents like Nenita, as she herself has been a high school graduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.
Nenita has been doing a trading business for years now. What she basically does is buy general merchandise from wholesalers, then sells items piecemeal at a small profit. Products can range from furniture to household appliances, electronic devices, clothing, and other items. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling prices and the many options that are offered. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 300 in sales every day.
To help her continue the operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 12,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy more quantity and variety of products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
Nenita dreams to be able to give her all her children a high-quality education through all her hard work from her business. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the groups weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives.
* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loan.use: to pay for additional merchandise to sell

loan.name: Mitooma Tumanyane Association, Bushenyi Group

texts.en: N. Betty is the leader of the Mitooma Tumanyane Association. She is 34 years-old and married with three children who are all in school. Betty has a retail shop that sells general merchandise to town residents in Mitooma. His shop is by the side of the road and this helps her to attract even passer by customers. She is able to make 90,000/= weekly income and she is grateful that she also sells bananas as a side business. She has had the business for four years and hard work and determination has enabled her to grow stronger. Her dream is to be able to set up another outlet in the future.She needs a loan to be able to buy more stock for her shop.

loan.use: to buy more stock for her shop

loan.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma M., 57, is a resident of Malaria, Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Lorenzo, a jeepney driver. She is the mother of five children; two are working, one is in high school, and the others have settled with their own families. At this time, she is working hard to send her youngest to college. This is the dream for most Filipino parents like Emma, as she herself is a college graduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.
Emma operates an auto-repair shop, offering repairs, check-ups and beautification of all types of cars and jeepneys - any type of vehicle that is referred to them. They also have a little refreshment stand in their auto-repair shop, where they sell beverages to the waiting customers and passing passenger vehicles. She earns a minimum of PHP 400 every day.
To help her continue the operation of her business, Emma is requesting a PHP 10,000 loan, which she will use to buy new machines and other materials needed for auto repairs. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
Emma dreams of expanding her business and enjoying a good and healthy life together with her family. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the groups weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God.
* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loan.use: to pay for new machines and other materials needed for auto repairs

loan.name: Margalaa

texts.en: Margalaa is 32 years old and lives with his wife and two children, aged 1 and 4, in Hovd province, Mongolia. They live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. His wife is a salesperson at Talst Optic, a private company. Margalaa operates a taxi service in his town. He started his business in 2004. He is a reliable and safe driver who is renowned amongst his customers. He is planning to continue his business in the future. He says, "All I want is to build a house where my family can live happily." He is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to buy a new car.

loan.use: To buy a new car

loan.name: Tajimurat

texts.en: Tajimurat A. lives in the region of Jilikul. He is 52 years old. He is a widower. His family is large, he has eight children. Two sons are now working in Moscow. Tajimurat sells bicycle spare parts from home. He has been in this business for more than thirteen years. His specializes in building bicycles and repairing vehicles. This is why this business is easy for him. He is asking for the loan to buy new spare parts for bicycles.

loan.use: to buy new bicycle spare parts

loan.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is 26 years old and works in the contracting business for glass and aluminum projects. He has 13 years of experience in this line of work. He works very hard. He is married and has one child, who is the most important thing in his life. He would like to provide a good life and education for his son. With a loan from al-Majmoua, he wants to buy glass and aluminum partitions for his business. He is ambitious and loves his profession, and he strives to develop his business even further. He has customers from his community and from among his neighbors. He stands out in his profession due to his thoroughness. He undertakes numerous projects at the same time in order to be able to provide for his family. People seek him out to hire him for their construction projects because of how he stands out in his field due to his attention to detail and his experience.

loan.use: to buy glass and aluminum partitions for his glass and aluminum contracting business.

loan.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita E., 53, is a resident of Pangarap Village, Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Julio, a carpenter. She is the mother of one child who is currently attending college. By the grace of God, Nenita has managed to support her child's schooling up to the college level. This is the dream for most Filipino parents like Nenita, as she herself is a college graduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.
Nenita has been running her own variety store for 12 years now. In the Philippines, a variety store is a place to go to buy cooking oil, a sachet of shampoo, an egg or even soft drinks and candies for PHP 5. She buys these items at wholesale prices and retails them with a minimum mark-up. She also sells cell phone load credits to all mobile phone networks operating in her local community. She earns an estimated net monthly income of around PHP10,000.
To help her continue the operation of her business, Nenita is requesting a PHP 14,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy more grocery items to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
Nenita dreams a of running a successful business and enjoying a good life and good health with the entire family. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the groups weekly fellowship* meetings where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God.
* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loan.use: to buy additional grocery items to replenish the stock of her variety store

loan.name: Anonymous Group
loan.use: To purchase matooke and maize

loan.name: Basem

texts.en: Basem is 36 years old and married with two children. He paints workshops and homes for a living, and also sells used clothing. He has five years of experience in these businesses. He likes his work, and he has a strong work ethic. He is ambitious and diligent in his work. He works in order to improve his and his family's financiA. situation and sociA. status. He strives to provide well for his family by working in a number of different fields, as he is having difficulty obtaining the materials he needs to run his primary business, which is painting homes and workshops. With a loan from A.-Majmoua, he would like to buy both new equipment, and also used clothes so that he can benefit from the revenues he generates by selling them. He aspires to change his materiA. situation by expanding his business and increasing his productivity.

loan.use: to buy new equipment for his painting business .

loan.name: Ibragim

texts.en: Ibragim B. lives in the region of Shahrituz. He is 45 years old. He is married and has three children. His son is now in Russia. Ibragim has higher education in accounting. He has worked in his profession for eight years. He is now in agriculture. He mainly grows vegetables, sows wheat and plants fruit trees. He has been in this business for six years. He is taking out the loan to buy mineral fertilizer, fuel and watermelon seeds. He wants to sow and gather a good harvest for resale.

loan.use: to buy mineral fertilizers, fuel and watermelon seeds

loan.name: Eliza

texts.en:
This is Eliza N., 32. She is a resident of Pangarap Village, Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Richienel N., her business partner. She is the mother of five children who are all in elementary and preparatory schooling. At this time, she is working hard to send her children all the way through college. This is the dream for most Filipino parents, like Eliza, as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can give to their children.
Eliza has been involved in buying and selling of various merchandise. Basically, she buys general merchandise from wholesalers and sells the items, piecemeal, with a small profit. Products can range from furniture to household appliances, electronic devices, clothing, and other items. Customers are attracted to buy her merchandise because of her low selling prices and the many options that are offered. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.
To help Eliza continue the operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP10,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
Eliza dreams to be able to give her all her children a high-quality education through all her hard work on her business. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the groups weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she received.
* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loan.use: to pay for additional merchandise to sell.

loan.name: Hasan

texts.en: Hasan is 43 years old and married with four children. He works as a driver for students and tourists. He has 15 years of experience in his field. He likes his work, and he supplements it by working as a driver for tourists during the high seasons of tourism. He stands out in his field through his good prices and his experience. He would like to secure a respectable standard of living for himself and for his family, and he is trying to improve his and his family's material situation and social status. With a loan from al-Majmoua, he would like to have maintenance and touch-ups done on the van he drives. He hopes to one day own his own vehicle, and even more so, he would like to have his own business, as he is ambitious, and devoted to and diligent in his work. He loves his family, and it is what he cares about most in life.

loan.use: to do necessary maintenence to his van.

loan.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret is currently in the business of selling maize and bread. She is 36 years old, married, and has 6 children. All of her children go to school.
Margret has borrowed a loan to stock more maize and bread to sell. She hopes to pay her children's school fees with the extra profits from her business in the future.

loan.use: To stock more maize and bread to sell.

loan.name: Samer

texts.en: Samer is 28 years old and unmarried. He works in a restaurant which serves all sorts of food. He has 12 years of experience in his field. He likes his work and stands out in it due to his attention to detail, the cleanliness of his establishment, the quality of his work, and his friendliness. He is always striving and making great efforts to secure a good future for himself since he aspires to start a family on a strong financiA. foundation. Because of this, he desires to develop his business so that he can one day own a big restaurant which sells every kind of food. With a loan from A.-Majmoua, he would like to buy ingredients and cooking oil for his restaurant. He has experience in his work, and he has customers from his community, from among his neighbors, and from among his relatives who all make a point to come to his restaurant because of how markedly delicious his food is.

loan.use: to buy ingredients and cooking oil for his restaurant.

loan.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is currently in the business of selling charcoal. She is 28 years old, married, and has 1 child who goes to school. Grace borrowed a loan to stock more charcoal to sell. She hopes to expand her business with the extra profits from her business in the future.

loan.use: To stock more charcoal to sell.

loan.name: Susan

texts.en:
This is Susan P., 49, a resident of Ascoville, Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Jose P., an overseas Filipino worker. She is the mother of five children, one of whom is already working while another is currently enrolled in college; one is in high school and two are enrolled in the local elementary school.
By the grace of God, Susan has managed to support her older children's schooling up to the college level. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her remaining children all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Susan, as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.
Susan operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 PHPs-worth of cooking oil or an egg. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She makes a profit by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling them at retail piece rates. She earns a minimum of 200 PHP in sales every day.
Susan is requesting a 17,000 PHP loan to buy more products like groceries, toiletries and beverages so as to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. Susan dreams of being able to give all of her children a good and high-quality education through all of her hard work in her business.
Susan prays for successful lives for all her children and hopefully they will able to send her children all the way through college. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she received.
*All CCT community members are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners that meet on a weekly basis. The fellowship groups gather to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loan.use: to pay for additional grocery items to replenishment inventory.

loan.name: Manuel

texts.es: Manuel tiene 38 aos de edad, es casado y tiene 3 hijos. Vive junto a su familia en el distrito de Olmos, una zona agrcola de bastante movimiento comercial que se encuentra situada en la provincia de Lambayeque, a ms de una hora y media de la ciudad de Chiclayo. Desde hace dos aos, se dedica a la crianza y venta de animales menores. Los cria en corrales ubicados en la parte posterior de su casa. Cuando los animales ya han alcanzado un buen punto de desarrollo, los vende en el mercado local. Desea aumentar su ganado con la compra de ms animales y alimento balanceado. Con esta inversin, sus animales podrn lograr un mejor tamao y peso y Manuel los podrn vender por un mejor precio. Para lograr sus metas, ha creido conveniente solicitar un prstamo de 2000 nuevos soles a Edpyme Alternativa. Posee muy buenas referencias personales y laborales de su comunidad rural. Agradece a los prestamistas de Kiva por su apoyo en crecer su negocio y ofrecerle una mejor vida a su familia.
texts.en:
38-year old Manuel is married and has three children. He and his family live in Olmos District, a busy commercial and agricultural area located in Lambayeque province, an hour and a half from the town of Chiclayo.
For the last two years Manuel has raised and sold livestock. He raises the calves in corrals located at the back of his house. When the young animals have reached an optimal stage of development, he sells them in the local market. He wishes to increase his herd by buying more cattle and nutritious feed. This will enable the animals to reach a good size and weight so he can sell them for a good price.
To achieve this goal, Manuel approached Kiva partner Edpyme Alternativa to ask for a loan of 2,000 soles. He has very good personal and work references from members of the local community. He is grateful to Kiva donors for their help in expanding his business and helping him provide his family with a better life.

loan.use: to buy more cattle and nutritious feed

loan.name: Jimmy

texts.en:
Jimmy is 66 years old, married to Anjeline and they have four children aged between 30, 25, 20 and 18 years old. He owns a farm in Mutwot trading centre and keeps dairy cows. He has been in the business for a period of 20 years getting a monthly income of KES 4,000.
Jimmy has gone further and borrowed a loan of KES. 40,000 from KADET LTD. This is his fourth term loan after he paid the previous loans successfully. He wishes to use the money to improve the farm and add more dairy cows. The profits will be used to educate his children to higher levels.
He hopes to have a happy family.

loan.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loan.name: Faiziya

texts.en:
Z. Faiziya is married and the loving mother of her child. Her husband is a driver. Faiziya works hard to provide for her family. She started her business with a small amount of capital and in time, expanded her business with the help of Imon International. At the present time, she has her own place at the market and she sells childrens clothes. She has been in this business for 15 years and she would like to get a loan of 3,000$ US to purchase new spring childrens clothes. She thanks all the lenders who support her and allow her to increase her assortment of goods, which will attract more customers.
More about Tajikistan and IMON International
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.
But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.
IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loan.use: To buy childrens clothes

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: to purchase a dairy cow and a water pump.

loan.name: Housein

texts.en: Housein is 24 years old and works in a gym. He has seven years of experience in this line of work. He likes his work and believes that he is providing his community with a service which benefits their health through his work. He has a lot of experience in his work, and his establishment stands out in his field given that there are few gyms in his area and given that the price of memberships at his gym is low. He would like to increase his income in order to be able to provide more people with the opportunity to exercise. With a loan from al-Majmoua, he would like to have some maintenance done on his gym, install a sound system, and improve some of the pieces of equipment in his gym. He is trying to secure a good future for himself, as well as start a family on a stable financial foundation.

loan.use: to finish the necessary maintenance to his gym, to install a sound system, and to repair equipments in his gym.

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: to purchase more cosmetics and beauty products.

loan.name: Asha

texts.en: Asha is currently in the business of selling sugar. She is 42 years old, married, with six children, all of whom go to school. Asha has requested a loan to buy more sugar for her stock. She hopes to expand her business with the extra profits.

loan.use: to buy more sugar to sell.

loan.name: Saidahmad

texts.en:
H. Saidahmad is married and has five children. He lives with his family in Dushanbe, Tajikistan. For the past 14 years he has been selling mens clothes in the market of Shohmansur in Dushanbe city. He buys goods and resells them with a small extra charge. He was also engaged in repairing apartments and houses. Today his working capital in his business is 6,000 US dollars ($US). Saidahmad would like to get a loan of 1400$US to buy new seasonal mens clothing according to the market demand and he hopes that lenders will support him.
More about Tajikistan and IMON International:
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.
But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the USSR, further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 per cent of the country is mountainous and only 7 per cent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.
IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loan.use: to buy seasonal men's clothes.

loan.name: Florita

texts.en:
Florita is a married woman with six children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Florita is 54 years old and has two children who are still in school.
Florita has a fish vending business in the Philippines. Florita requested a PHP 12,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy more fish to sell in her stall.
Florita has been 5 years in this business. In the future, Florita would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college and expand her business.

loan.use: To buy more fish to sell in her stall.

payment.comment: Over-reported by partner. Reduced to local price.

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: to purchase timber for resale.

loan.name: Jihad

texts.en:
Jihad is a young man from Saffarein village close to Tulkarem city in the northern part of Palestine, Jihad is employed by a small agency in Saffarein that transports goods and items for commercial stores and shops inside Saffarein and between Tulkarem and Saffarein village.
Jihad took a loan from FATEN to repay relatives and friends as he had borrowed money from them while he was a student and now that he works and can take out a loan to repay only FATEN from his monthly salary.
Jihad appears in the picture here in FATEN's branch in Tulkarem.

loan.use: Pay back his relatives and friends who covered his college fees

loan.name: Lucita

texts.en:
This is Lucita D., 68. Lucita is a high school graduate. She is a widow with two children who are helping her in the business. She lives with her sons and grandchildren in LD subdivision, Tala, Caloocan City, Philippines.
Lucita manages a glass/aluminium workshop located along the national highway, where her son is the chief worker, along with two other assistants. Lucita deals with customers while her son and her two other employees do the hard work. Their shop fabricates and installs aluminium and glass doors, windows and building panels. They earn an estimated net income of around 12,000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) a month.
To help her continue operating her business, Lucita is requesting a 30,000 PHP loan. She plans to use this loan to buy more materials needed as requested by the customers. She expects a boost in her income through this loan.
Lucita dreams that her business will be successful and wants to open another branch to generate employment in her local community. She prays for good health and a peaceful, happy life for her family. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of god she receives.
*All CCT community members are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners that meet on a weekly basis. The fellowship groups gather to study the word of god, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loan.use: to pay for materials for her doors and windows business.

loan.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria, a 43-year-old lady originally from Jombang-East Java Province, is married to Lukas and has been blessed with two children: Diva, who is 3 years old, and Glen, who is aged 3 months. When they got married, Lukas, a widower, also brought four children from his first marriage, so Maria is also taking care of them. They all reside in Airnona Village.

Living with six children is not easy for Maria, as there are many things they need to be provided with such as food, education, clothes, etc. Moreover, they are growing up, requiring Maria and her husband to work even harder to generate money. Because Lukas doesnt have a permanent job, he cannot provide a stable monthly income, so Maria took the initiative to start a kiosk business eight months ago, using her own capital. She is a kind-hearted woman willing to help her husband meet their daily needs.

Maria heard that TLM provides a loan program to small entrepreneurs, and because she wants to improve her business is now requesting a loan of IDR 5,000,000 from TLM to purchase items for her kiosk such as eggs, biscuits, snacks, instant noodles etc. She hopes that TLM is willing to provide the loan for the improvement of her business and family welfare in the future.

loan.use: to purchase items for the kiosk such as eggs, biscuits, snacks, instant noodles, etc.

loan.name: Parsanika

texts.en:
Parsanika O. P., 45, is married and the father of four children: John, aged 18 years, in college; Silus, aged 11 years, in class six; Susan, aged 16 years, in form one, and Mary, aged 14 years, in class eight. They live in Kitengela.
Parsanika is a livestock trader and his business is at Kitengela market, which is a busy market where most of his clients are.
He was introduced to KADET Ltd. by a client of KADET. Parsanikas business of 12 years gives him a monthly profit of KES 5,000. This loan of KES 80,000 is his first loan from KADET Ltd. With it, he plans to purchase more livestock for sale.
If the loan boosts his business, he plans to open a butchery. Parsanika dreams of becoming a sO. meat supplier in Kitegela. He describes himself as hardworking.

loan.use: to purchase more livestock

loan.name: Ikrom

texts.en:
Ikrom K. is married and has one child.
He sells mens clothes, such as shirts, pants, underwear and ties in the market of Shohmansur in Dushanbe city. He purchases goods from suppliers who export the goods from China and Bishkek city.
He plans to purchase new seasonal mens clothes, and for this reason he has requested a loan of US $2,500.
More about Tajikistan and IMON International: Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes having been a key post along the Silk Road and having witnessed the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to epic mountain passes, a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC, and communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.
But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still lives in abject poverty.
IMON's History: Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj

loan.use: to buy a new assortment of mens clothes

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: to purchase more essential goods.

loan.name: Anna

texts.en:
Anna J. is 30 years old, married and the mother of three children. She owns a beauty salon in Changamwe, Mombasa, that has been in operation for 10 years.
This is Annas second financing from KADET Ltd., and she plans to purchase more beauty products and detergents for her salon.
Anna hopes to expand her business with the anticipated profits from the loan. In the future, she hopes to open more salon outlets in Mombasa.

loan.use: to purchase more beauty products and detergents

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: to purchase a dairy cow and a chuff cutter

loan.name: Buhairi

texts.en:
Buhairi K. is 43 years old and lives in the town of Natete in the Kampala central region of Uganda. He is married and has three children. All of his children are currently in school. Buhairi has rental houses, which he has had for five years.
To help expand his business, Buhairi has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase or construct more rental houses. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Buhairi hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his children. In the future, Buhairi hopes to expand his business.

loan.use: to purchase or construct more rental houses.

loan.name: Kihani Turiise Group, Ibanda

texts.en:
K. Medius is the leader of Kihani Turiise group in Ibanda. She is 50 years old, married, and has four children.
She has a business of selling produce from Kihani with the help of her husband. She has been in the business for over 20 years. She also has a farm from which she sells matooke (green plantain) and coffee. She is able to make 100,000 UGX as weekly profits and she is also involved in the sale of milk and goats. She is very hard working and cooperative and her dream is to be able to educate all her children and have an expanded project. She needs a loan to be able to purchase more produce for resale.

loan.use: to purchase more produce for resale

loan.name: Belinda

texts.en:
This is Belinda B., 45, a resident of Malaria, Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Vicente B., a mason, and is the mother of two children, who are both studying at public elementary and high schools nearby. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her children all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Belinda, as she herself is an elementary graduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.
Belinda operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 PHPs-worth of cooking oil or an egg. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She makes a profit by buying supplies at wholesale prices and selling them at retail rates. She earns a minimum of 200 PHP in sales every day.
To help her continue operation of her variety store, she is requesting a 12,000 PHP loan. She plans to use this loan to buy more products like groceries, toiletries and beverages so as to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
Belinda dreams of being able to give all of her children a good and high-quality education through all of her hard work in her business. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the groups weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she received.
*All CCT community members are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners that meet on a weekly basis. The fellowship groups gather to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loan.use: to pay for additional grocery items for her variety store.

loan.name: Dias Francisco

texts.pt:
Dias Francisco B. nasceu no Distrito de Guija, Provncia de Gaza, sul de Moambique casado pai de 5 filhos de idades entre 5 a 18 anos de idade, destes 4 va a Escola. Fez somente 7 classe no continuou devido a dificuldades financeiras pelos pais. Vive na casa prpria com a sua famlia e na sustenta mais ninguem.
Saiu de Guija para Maputo a procura de melhores condies de vida, possui um negocio proprio de venda de produtos de primeira necessidade ha mais de 7 anos. Na tem empregado e consegue um rendimento de cerca de 4.000.00mt por ms que aplica nas despesas de casa e a vezes consegue poupar algum na sua conta bancaria.
Nunca teve emprstimo em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku atravs de amigo que cliente desta instituio.Este o seu terceiro emprstimo na Hluvuku no valor de 15.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar mercadoria (leo, Feijo, caldos, cebola e outros) para aumentar a quantidade da sua mercadoria. Os emprestimos anteriores foram de 15.000.00mt ambos e foram para o comercio.
Compromete se a pagar devidamente para poder aceder a outros crditos no futuro. Pretende solicitar novos emprstimos para concluir a construo de dependencias e da sua loja.
texts.en:
Dias Francisco Biza was born in Guija District, Gaza Province in southern Mozambique. He is married and has five children aged 5 to 18; four of them go to school. Dias only finished seventh grade and did not continue with school because his parents had financial difficulties. He lives in his own house with his family and has no other dependents.
He left Guija to move to Maputo looking for better living conditions. For more than seven years he has had his own business selling staple goods. He has no employees and earns an income of about 4,000 meticais per month which he uses for household expenses. Sometimes he manages to save some money in his bank account.
Dias has never had loans from other banks. He learned about Hluvuku through a friend who is a customer of this institution. This is his third Hluvuku loan, and he is asking for 15,000 meticais, which he will use to buy merchandise (oil, beans, broth, onions and other items) to increase his inventory. The previous loans were both for 15,000 meticais, and both were for the business.
He promises to make his payments on time so he can take out more loans in the future. He intends to ask for other loans in order to finish building some rooms and his shop.

loan.use: to buy merchandise (oil, beans, broth, onions and other items)

loan.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy has been in the farming business for 11 years with more concentration on bananas, maize, and milk in the Nkubu area, Central Kenya. She is married with three children aged 21,16 and 8 years old and all schooling. She relies on farming for the family upkeep.
Mercy has made a third loan request of 80,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to carry out an expansion of her banana plantation acreage and buy more poultry. Her first and second loans of 30,000 and 50,000 KES respectively were promptly repaid.
Mercy says lack of water for irrigation and animal diseases remain her farming challenge but is optimistic with all her businesses.

loan.use: To pay for expansion of her banana plantation and buy poultry.

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: to purchase more essential goods.

loan.name: Achola

texts.en: J., a 46-year-old married mother of four school-going children, is currently in the business of selling bedsheets. J. has requested a loan to stock more bedsheets to sell, and hopes to construct a house for her family in the future with the extra profits arising from her business.

loan.use: to stock more bedsheets to sell.

loan.name: Upendo Kahembe Group

texts.fr: Zamuda M. est entrepreneur, prsidente du groupe daffaire Upendo Kahembe , ge de 53 ans, veuve, mre de 7 enfants dont 3 frquentent lcole et 4 ont leur propres foyers. Son mari fut dcd il y a longtemps. La cliente Zamuda M. est vendeuse des habits (boubous femmes et habits de juniors). Elle expose ses produits dans un magasin, son domicile et parfois auprs des preneurs fonctionnaire souvent agents des entreprises publiques. Elle vient de raliser 4 ans oprationnels en bnficiant de crdit de lIMF Hekima. Ce nouveau crdit doit lui servir de sapprovisionner avec des nouvelles marchandises au niveau de Tanzanie (50 boubous, 50 complets juniors, 30 boubous hommes, pantalons jeans, Los, et l'autre somme dargent servira pour le frais douanier, etc.). En plus, elle ambitionne agrandir son entreprise, construire confortablement une maison, acheter une voiture jeep pour son dplacement. La cliente Zamuda M. remercie Hekima pour ses actions en faveur de pauvres veuves exclus de banque classique. Il sied de signaler que le groupe daffaire Upendo kahembe est majoritairement fminins.
texts.en: Zamuda M. is an entrepreneur and president of the Upendo Kahembe business group. She is a 53-year-old widow and mother of seven, three of whom are still in school and four of whom run their own households. Her husband passed away a long time ago. Zamuda M. sells clothing (womens boubous and childrens clothing). She sells her products in a store, from her home and sometimes to customers who are government employees, particularly officials from public corporations. She has just celebrated her four-year anniversary of being in operation, supported by a loan from the MFI Hekima. This new loan will help her increase her inventory with new merchandise from Tanzania (50 boubous, 50 childrens outfits, 30 mens boubous, jeans, including Los brand jeans, and the remaining funds will help her cover customs charges, etc.). She also hopes to expand her business, to be able to afford to build a house and to buy a jeep for greater mobility. Zamuda M. would like to thank Hekima for its work on behalf of widows living in poverty without access to conventional banks. Its worth mentioning that the Upendo Kahembe group is majority female.

loan.use: 50 boubous, 50 childrens' outfits, 30 mens' boubous, jeans, and Los brand jeans, with the remaining funds going to cover customs charges, etc.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loan.name: Lukia

texts.en:
Lukia N. is 38 years old and lives in the town of Natete in the Kampala central region of Uganda. She is married and has three children. All of her children are currently in school. Lukia has a small retail shop, which she has had for five years. She also has a second business: a restaurant.
To help expand her business, Lukia has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase essential merchandise like sugar for resale. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Lukia hopes to generate greater profits and buy food for her family. In the future, Lukia hopes to expand her business.

loan.use: to purchase essential goods like sugar for resale.

loan.name: Aigul's Group

texts.en:
Aigul A. is the leader of this group. She is 37 years old and married to a private entrepreneur. She has two daughters and a son; all of the children study at school.
A year ago, with an initial investment of 5,000 KGS, Aigul started a company called Siberian Health to sell medicines and cosmetics. In this way she earns 4,000 KGS per month. She hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to purchase more cosmetics and medicines in order to increase the turnover of her business. In the future she wants to provide her children with a good education and believes that her job will help to improve the familys living conditions.
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loan.use: to purchase cosmetics and medicines.

loan.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
This is Marilyn V., 46, a resident of Admin Site, Tala, Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Gilberto V., a security officer, and is the mother of three children, two of whom are already working. The other child is still studying in college. At this time, Marilyn is working hard to be able to send her youngest child all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Marilyn, as she herself has been a high school graduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.
Marilyn runs a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that sells groceries, toiletries and beverages in small amounts to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, five Philippine pesos' worth of cooking oil or an egg. Her store is located next to her house. Marilyn also sells viands (prepared dishes) just beside her small variety store. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She makes a profit by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling them at retail piece rates. She earns a minimum of 300 Philippine pesos (PHP) in sales every day.
To help her continue running her businesses, she is requesting a 10,000 PHP loan. She plans to use this loan to buy more products such as groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She will also use part of this loan to purchase raw ingredients for her food stall. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
Marilyn dreams of being able to give all of her children a good and high-quality education through all of her hard work in her business. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the groups weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of god she receives.
